Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Auction Design in Constrained Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The PI will consider two facets of auction design that are not only of fundamental importance, but also have defied significant positive results despite extensive research in the economics literature. These facets arise from practical constraints imposed on auctions: Budget constraints on the bidders, and asymmetric and incomplete information between the bidder and auctioneer. The PI seeks to develop and employ techniques from theoretical computer science, particularly approximation algorithms, adversarial mechanism design, stochastic control, and learning theory to develop novel tools and techniques to address these questions. The intellectual merit of the proposed research will be in blending, encompassing, and extending work on related problems in theoretical computer science, economics, stochastic decision theory, and computational learning, thereby developing new theoretical models and solutions, which in turn will impact the respective disciplines. Furthermore, it is imperative to develop such tools since the facets we consider will become critical to the successful deployment of auctions in several modern internet-based settings. The proposed work will also be broadly disseminated via workshops and specialized courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The goal of this project was to understand the behavior of systems with multiple self-interested participants. Such systems arise in diverse settings: Auctions where buyers are self-interested and can misreport valuations; cluster computing systems with multiple tenants who are only interested in the performance of their own tasks; voting systems where voters care about how fair the outcome is to them; societies where individuals care about the prevelance of their own point of view; and so on. In an increasingly online and connected world, it becomes imperative to model and understand the performance of such systems, in order to better engineer them.

This project has made fundamental contributions to our understanding of auctions, opinion formation, fairness in scheduling theory, and decentralized decision making across time. This includes the first approximation results for auction design when bidders are constrained by budgets or when their valuations are influenced by others in a social network; game-theoretic modeling, analysis, and preliminary experimental validation of opinion formation processes in networks; bounding the degradation in performance of decentralized decision making over time compared to centralized decision making; and understanding the tradeoff between fairness and performance in data center scheduling. 

Broader Impacts. This project has spawned subsequent work in auction design that have built on this work. There is collaborative work underway to implement fairness concepts in a real data center scheduler as well as in certain types of voting systems. The PI has co-written a survey on approximating optimal auctions, and presented a tutorial on stochastic optimization that is related to this work. This project has supported three graduate students who have all successfully completed their PhDs, two of who have followed academic paths. It has also supported a postdoc who is now a faculty member, as well as supported the senior thesis of an undergraduate student.
